overview: Appealing to the tax tribunal - the First-tier Tribunal (Tax) - against tax decisions: how to appeal, going to a hearing, and what to do if you lose your case
title: Tax tribunal

table.body:
You can appeal to the tax tribunal if you disagree with a tax decision by HMRC, eg a tax assessment or penalty.

You can also appeal if your goods are seized by HMRC, the UK Border Agency or the Serious Organised Crime Agency (SOCA).

##Appealing against tax decisions

You can appeal against a decision about:

- a direct tax - eg Income Tax, PAYE tax, Corporation Tax or Capital Gains Tax, National Insurance contributions, Statutory Sick Pay
- an indirect tax - eg VAT, excise duty, Insurance Premium Tax

See lists of [taxes you can appeal against](/self-assessment-appeals/what-you-can-appeal-against "taxes you can appeal against").

If the decision is about a direct tax, you must [appeal to HMRC](/self-assessment-appeals/ "appeal to HMRC") first.

If it's about a tax assessment for an indirect tax, you usually have to pay the tax before you can appeal.

If this will cause you serious problems, ask HMRC or the tribunal if your case can go ahead without the payment.

^Tax credit appeals are dealt with by the [social security and child support tribunal](/social-security-child-support-tribunal/overview "social security and child support tribunal").^

##Appeals about seized goods

You can appeal to the tribunal if customs or SOCA officers seize your goods and refuse to return them.

You must ask the organisation that seized your goods to review its decision before you appeal to the tribunal.

##Help and advice

You can represent yourself, or [find a legal adviser,](http://legaladviserfinder.justice.gov.uk/ "find a legal adviser"){:rel="external"} tax adviser or accountant to help with your appeal.

You usually have to pay your own costs.

You can get free advice from:

- [Citizens Advice](http://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/ "Citizens Advice"){:rel="external"}
- [TaxAid](http://www.taxaid.org.uk "TaxAid"){:rel="external"}
- [TaxHelp for Older People](http://www.taxvol.org.uk "TaxHelp for Older People"){:rel="external"} - if you're over 60

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
*[PAYE]: Pay As You Earn
*[SOCA]: Serious Organised Crime Agency

table.title: Appeal to the tribunal

table.body:
The tribunal decides on appeals about small tax penalties after reading the appeal form and other paperwork.

In these cases, the tribunal will write to you with details of what you need to do.

In all other cases the tribunal will usually hold a hearing.

They will try to hold this near your home or workplace, and will usually give you at least 14 days' notice of the date.

##What you should bring to a hearing

Make sure you bring:

- the 'statement of case'
- your response
- any other documents you'll be relying on - eg invoices, accounts or bank statements

##Who will be at a hearing

The hearing will be attended by:

- a tribunal panel - which can include a tribunal judge and expert members
- a tribunal clerk
- a representative from the department/agency (eg HMRC)
- any witnesses

You can bring a representative and a friend, family member or colleague.

##What happens at a hearing

You or your representative will normally put your case first, saying why the decision is wrong and giving facts to support your argument.

The department's or agency's representative will then present the case for the other side.

The tribunal may also ask questions during the hearing.

You can find out more about what happens at a hearing in the booklet below:

$D [Download 'At your tax tribunal hearing' (PDF, 92KB)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/tribunals/tax/forms-and-how-to-appeal/at-your-hearing.pdf "Download 'At your tax tribunal hearing' (PDF, 92KB)"){:rel="external"} $D

##Getting the decision

You will either get the decision on the day of the hearing or in writing shortly afterwards.

*[HMRC]: Her Majesty's Revenue & Customs
table.title: How your appeal is decided

table.body:
##Ask the tribunal to reconsider

You can ask the tribunal to reconsider the case if there was something wrong with the way it was handled, eg:

- you didn't receive paperwork about the case
- someone didn't turn up for your hearing

##Ask for permission to appeal

You may be able to appeal against the decision if the tribunal made a legal mistake, eg it didn't:

- apply the law correctly
- give good reasons for its decision

To ask for permission to appeal, use the form below:

$D [Download 'Application for permission to appeal to Upper Tribunal (Tax and Chancery) Chamber' (PDF, 35KB)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/forms/tribunals/tax/appeal-upper-tribunal-form.pdf "Download 'Application for permission to appeal to Upper Tribunal (Tax and Chancery) Chamber' (PDF, 35KB)"){:rel="external"} $D

$D [Download 'Application for permission to appeal to Upper Tribunal (Tax and Chancery) Chamber' (DOC, 124KB)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/forms/tribunals/tax/appeal-upper-tribunal-form.doc "Download 'Application for permission to appeal to Upper Tribunal (Tax and Chancery) Chamber' (DOC, 124KB)"){:rel="external"} $D

$D [Download 'Guidance on applying for permission to appeal to Upper Tribunal (Tax and Chancery) Chamber' (PDF, 37KB)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/tribunals/tax/forms-and-how-to-appeal/appealing-upper-tribunal-form-completion-guide.pdf "Download 'Guidance on applying for permission to appeal to Upper Tribunal (Tax and Chancery) Chamber' (PDF, 37KB)"){:rel="external"} $D

%You must ask for permission to appeal within 56 days of the date of the full written decision.%

Send the completed form to:

$A
First-tier Tribunal (Tax)  
3rd Floor  
Temple Court  
35 Bull Street  
Birmingham  
B4 6EQ 
$A

$C 
<taxappeals@hmcts.gsi.gov.uk>  
0845 223 8080
$C


##After you send the form

A judge will decide if you can take your case to a higher tribunal, called the [Upper Tribunal (Tax and Chancery).](http://www.justice.gov.uk/tribunals/tax-and-chancery-upper-tribunal "Upper Tribunal (Tax and Chancery)"){:rel="external"}
